description.text: The numbers on my mailbox are starting to fall off due to the weather. So rather then buy new ones, I chose to print them. These numbers are actually the FORTE font and set at 4 inches high. I extruded them 4mm thick for a nice solid piece. the nail/screw holes are modeled in as well.

• Print your numbers as needed.
  • Paint if you want. (make sure you use plastic frendly outdoor paint)
  • Mount using nails or I actually prefer screws so they don't work back out as the temperatures go up and down.
    • Note: I printed mine in PLA and on a 90+ degree day they did get a little soft. ABS may be the better choice. If you do print a set keep an eye on them for a couple days to make sure they don't get too soft and start to curl.

comments.text: What font is used? i need letters to for the local ham club
comments.author: boelle

comments.text: Thanks for making this!  It was really, really hard to find this in search for some reason.  I knew someone had to have made one, but -- maybe this could use a few more tags.  :)
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: Opened up 3.stl in Blender and couldn't find the object...  Did autozoom to find it and it's waaaaaay off to the side, perhaps 100,000 or more units off to the side, so far that floating point errors are causing rendering issues.  Can deal with that, but might cause people a lot of confusion FYI.

remixed_from.author: Mike01Hu
remixed_from.title: Velleman K8200 Printed Circuit Board Cover with Fan

description.text: This is a remake of the k8200 control board case found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:168769/#files It has mounts for two 40mm fans and increased wiring room at the top and base of the case and uses the original designs base plate for mounting the control board.

Print the original board cover base, mount control board to it. Print the new double fan case and screw it to the base plate. Mount two 40mm fans.  
I have opted to put the fans on the outside of the case as it was a bit cramped inside the case when internally mounted.

title: Arctic Cat Hood/Clutch Cover Bungee Holder

description.text: Made this for my Arctic Cat El Tigre when the bungee holder for the clutch cover broke. It is also the same design as the ones that the hood bungees go onto. Hope this helps someone else! (:
Built in Google Sketchup 2013.

author: thegcon

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:279864 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=279864

This is a head-base that can be used to build a puppet-, plushie-, robot- or even a fursuit-head. Fake fur can be glued on. I did not include the lower jaw because It's faster to make one with an aluminium-profile when to print it.
The holes for the eyes were enlarged to accomodate the eye- and eyelid mechanic to install http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:198945

The puppet sized head was printed in PLA without support material - took 8h 23min on my Makerbot 1 Dual. I printed the nose with raft and support.
I glue the parts together with Plaast (from http://www.plaast.de/).
I did not include the lower jaw because It's faster to make one with an aluminium-profile when to print it. It is covered with Wonderflex.
The ears are made of felt.
You can see the puppet-head in this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kXUzgVE4PJQ

comments.text: What scale would this need to be printed at for a fursuit?
comments.author: Epicdivision

comments.text:
I scaled the head to 230mm width (which is also the maximum for my 3d-printer) - it works for me, but people with larger heads might need to make it bigger (it's a tight fit).
http://tioh.livejournal.com/91839.html
http://tioh.livejournal.com/94162.html

This allows you to quickly take an "eye-power" view of a glass microscope slide, using a smart phone camera.  The resulting images can be used in "Tumor Board" or Clinical Pathology Conference (CPC) and for general teaching purposes.  This is ideal for demonstrating sub-macroscopic details and features like the junction between tumor and normal structures.

• Download and print.

  • Place a slide in the holder with the label down to obscure the label.

  • Put a piece of white plastic (cut up plate will work).

  • Take picture as close as focal point of smart phone camera will allow.
    • I used an Up!3D printer with design in trueSpace.

author: shortythe2nd

description.text:
Got a request from a friend for a wall hanger in gold with an anchor motif.  
Solved by modifying the "Spline Anchor Necklace" by Cesear to a wall hanger.  
Had to spray paint the print in order to get the gold look.

Modified the "Spline Anchor Necklace" by Cesear to a wall hanger in OpenSCAD by copying the hook part and moving it out of the plane. Added the holes. To change or remove holes modify the OpenSCAD files.  
Printed sideways with support for maximal strength of the hanger part. in 0.1 mm resolution on a Makerbot Replicator 2.  
Spray painted the print with a standard gold spray bought in the nearest store in order to get the gold look.

description.text: Cleaning laboratory benchtop surfaces is continuous and this small tool helps get a little bit of extra pressue on the job. Two of its edges can be used as a small scrapers.  If you fold some paper towels in the middle it serves as a quick sponge or squeege.

• Download either of the two models and print them out.

  • Scale the to whatever works for your needs.

  • Use edges as scrapers or fold paper towels in middle section to serve as a squeege or sponge.
    • Printed on Up!3D in ABS with design in trueSpace.

With Passover approaching, my wife (who is a rabbi) challenged me to create a vertical seder plate. I ended up designing a seven piece assembly that holds the traditional seder plate liners. OpenSCAD came to the rescue as the tolerances on the pieces was critical for it to be stable. I have included the source if you want to tweak the design. The arms can be rotated independently in order to fit the items as needed. Note: Seder plate liners are available in plastic and glass (with lettering) from a number of sources. Just Google "seder plate liners" and you'll be set. Update 1: I added a larger base that also has thinner spokes. Update 2: It worked nicely for two seders. One advantage to the Vertical Seder Plate is everyone could see the items versus a regular plate that lays flat on the table. Update 3 (April 2, 2015): Stratasys selected this design for their Passover e-card. Update 4 (April 5, 2015): Feature article on 3ders.org:
http://www.3ders.org/articles/20150405-maker-creates-modern-3d-printed-vertical-seder-plate-for-celebrating-passover.html

I used the following settings on my MakerBot Replicator2 to print the pieces. I didn't use a raft and support is not needed. Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 You will need to print one base, one arm_top and five arms in order to make the complete Seder Tree. Note for OpenSCAD users: There is one file for both the arm and arm_top. Just change the variable "top" depending on what you want to print.

description.text:
53 mm by 45 mm cylinder.
It fills the standard hole in a door when there is no nob or bolt.
Plastic shrinkage will give you a bit of play, you might wrap it once with tape to fill the small gap, or scale it up by what ever amount your plastic shrinks. or just tape over the plug end.

comments.text: It looks much better than the wash rag that was crammed through the hole.

comments.text: Simply brilliant -- thank you for posting this idea. I've been staring at a taped-over hole in one of my doors for over a year and never thought of this! Mine (Stanley steel door) needed a 55mm diameter plug, plus I added a flange on one side to seal out the weather.

My 3 year old was always knocking over the bridge so I made a clip to support the joins. It's based on a 'Melissa and Doug' set but I believe other sets are compatible
I scaled the stl file 2.54 in Repetier-Host because of some metric/english conversion issues.

comments.text: Nice design. My 3 year old boy will appreciate !
comments.author: tito7812

description.text: Hose clamp designed to control liquid flow through nylon/silicon tube. I made it for a siphon hose on my fish tank. I just pinch it close and it seals the pipe. Suits 10mm ID nylon tubing. Printed in green ABS, 0.3mm layers/solid fill on UP! Plus.

• Print for use with 10mm Nylon tubing. Scale up/down to suit your application. There may be a little trial and error.
    3. Print out as shown in the photo to reduce support and add strength.
  • Slide onto section of hose and squeeze as you pull back thumb tab gently.
  • Pull back on thumb tab to release.

comments.author: tlalexander

comments.text: I am currently using a licence of the software I use (I think you know the one) from a friends work. I just can't afford it myself. I don't want it coming back to him.
comments.author: tlalexander

comments.text:
You might be interested in FreeCAD ...
( http://sourceforge.net/projects/free-cad/http://sourceforge.net/project... )
comments.author: Tim_C

comments.text: I was just going to say that! FreeCAD is buggy at times, but if you stick to PARTS and some limited mirroring and arrays you can make it work. I'm willing to help if you get stuck somewhere.
comments.author: talpa

comments.text: Great thanks for the file! I service 3D systems Z printers and needed clamps for removing the binder tanks.... I just removed the upper notches to allow more space between the 2 walls, they served no purpose any way other than binding the 2 walls together?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I added them as I was still experimenting with it and wasn't sure how many notches I needed. It printed separated on my UP! but someone below said it printed connected as well. Whatever works for you, thats why I put it up... Glad you could make use of it. I am at UNI doing design so it is really good to hear.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: does it need support to print?
comments.author: meirm

comments.text: I just got done printing it flat like in the picture. Check out the "I made one" picture.
comments.author: meirm

comments.text: I am glad it worked out for you. I designed it in the compressed state so there wasn't too much stress on the abs. If was printed 'open' by the time the plastic bends around into the fully locked position it has undergone a pretty severe bend.
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text: I finally got it open, but for me I needed a knife. works great though! Thanks.
comments.author: Tim_C

comments.text: Good to hear. Maybe I should adjust the tolerance a little...
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text: Great design!

title: Intex K2 Inflatable Kayak Paddle Clip

description.text: Paddle clip that clips onto the sides of your Intex K2 Inflatable Kayak so that you can clip your Paddles down.

Print and clip onto Kayak.
Print 4 (2 for each side) for maximum stability and to hold yours and your kayaking partner's paddles (K2 is a two man kayak)
Not sure if this will work on any other kayaks or not as it was designed exclusively for the Intex Challenger K2. Could possible work with the K1.

comments.text: Nunca he impreso, por lo que no tengo una imagen. Hay una llanta que se infla, creo que diseñado para pinzar sobre ese borde. Espero que esto ayude!

author: kojo-jojo

title: Mendel90 spool holder for small spool

description.text:
I love my Mendel90, but the spool holders were designed for 30cm/2.3kg spools, and I'm buying 19cm/1kg spools, so I did what a good 3D printer owner should do, I printed my solution!  
Designed using SketchUp!

comments.text: This design does NOT work with my 170x85 mm (diameter, width) 1kg PLA spool because the gap is too narrow.  The spacing is likely for narrower spool with (< 70mm) width.
comments.author: csunwc

author: Laranjo3D

title: Gauge for electrical outlets / Gabarit pour prises electriques

description.text:
Allows to easily make holes of electrical outlets (french standard), verticaly or horizontaly.  
FR : Permet de faire facilement les trous pour les prises electriques en pose verticale ou horizontale

• Poser le gabarit dans un trou de scie cloche (diamètre 67cm)

  • Mettre le gabarit de niveau avec un niveau à bulle

  • Avec un crayon faire une marque au point de traçage voulu.
    Ce point sera le centre du future trou de scie cloche de la seconde prise.

author: pallier

description.text: Go here for the Customizer version.

A photo of me with each pixel rendered as a different size diamond corresponding to brightness. The pixels are connected in columns like beads on a string. The model is generated with a Customizer script which will allow you to upload your own images and tweak the pixel bead style a bit. However, as written, the design is very slow to compile and the results are kind of tricky to slice and print. I'd like to be able to recommend reliable settings for easy printing, so I think I'll refrain from publishing the customizer until I can figure out some fixes.

comments.text:
I tried to do this in a 50x50, it took 3 hrs 54min rendering in OpenSCAD.
Upon saving it said : openscad object isn't a valid 2-manifold and i couldn't save it... so sad because the rendering looked very nice.
Don't know how to solve this. Any help is appreciated.
comments.author: hobbybob

comments.text: Check out this version rewritten by jsc - it should render faster and possibly fixes some of the bugs too. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:310541
comments.author: hobbybob

comments.text:
Amazing! Just made one now, this is great. Would it be possible to up
the size a little to a 30x30 grid? I have been experimenting with images
and 30x30 is so much more recognisable than 20x20.
comments.author: Poitaman

comments.text: Yeah! If you are comfortable using OpenSCAD (1) directly, you can download the customizer script (2) and change the width/height variables and 20x20 label to any values you desire, then paste in new picture data created with the Thingiverse image_array tool (3). Or, once you change the dimension variables you could re-upload the script to Thingiverse as a remix tagged "customizer". (I'd be happy to do so if you prefer, but am equally content to encourage others to give it a go.)
comments.author: Poitaman

comments.text: We tried this and found changing brightness contrast and saturation settings in a photo editor helped. You want as much contrast or shadowing between facial features as possible.
comments.author: hokie94

comments.text: Are there suggestions/tips on what picture makes for the best results?  I tried a couple of photos and they're not too visible.
comments.author: ukcat

comments.text: same issues...i would like some suggestions as to what pic makes a good print.
comments.author: ukcat

comments.text: Good question. As hokie94 mentions, a lot of contrast between features helps. Consider saving the image in grayscale before you upload it, so you can see it the way the customizer will see it. You want the light areas to be white and the dark areas to be black (or nearly so). Otherwise, if the shades are too similar, all the pixels will appear about the same size.
comments.author: dmurphy

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback and the model!
comments.author: anoved

comments.text: As said above, I went into photoshop and did a convert to B&W (rather than just convert to greyscale). I then resized the image to 20x20 pixels.Went into the levels and crushed the blacks a bit. Then adjusted the contrast up and moved the midpoint a little.
comments.author: ukcat

comments.text: super cool... would you mind if i borrow the idea to make a grasshopper script? i am more comfortable with that
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: Go ahead.
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: really cool idea. especially impressive is the fact that you can use it to project the image. can't wait to see the .scad...
comments.author: atartanian

comments.text: Yeah, the diffraction blurring in the shadow can actually make the image more recognizable!
comments.author: atartanian

comments.text: This is pretty cool.  Could you upload the .scad?  Just don't tag it customizer if it's too slow.  I'd like to take a look at it to see if I can come up with a way to make it faster.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Thanks for the interest. I've uploaded the .scad file and photos of a circular version to this Thing. I would appreciate some feedback on the script, since it actually doesn't display as expected in Customizer - the panel appears solid. Perhaps a problem with the resize command? I haven't investigated in depth - could be something else.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Oh and you should try extruding 2d shapes wherever possible which should make it compile faster.  I noticed you're using cubes for the grid lines, try making them squares.  Also try eliminating the minkowski and the cylinder in the base shape and replace it with circles, etc.
comments.author: anoved

comments.text: Thanks for the tips! Incidentally my original plan was to make each strand of pixels a single extruded polygon, but I couldn't quite figure out how to generate the points array given OpenSCAD's immutable arrays.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Customizer is running OpenSCAD 2013.06 and I think your script suffers from the bug that version had with the resize() function when you resize something < 0, thereby shrinking. You could try rewriting it so that you do not shrink to work around it...
comments.author: anoved

comments.text: I posted a remix incorporating the fixes you recommended and now it works nicely. Thanks!
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: I'm glad to see people like the idea! I will try to post the customizer tomorrow.
comments.author: anoved

comments.text: another very cool customizer idea!  I can't wait to try it.
comments.author: joefe

comments.text: Great idea! Keep up the good job!
comments.author: Matterthings

comments.text: Yes, very cool!
comments.author: alexhb

comments.text: cool idea!

remixed_from.author: ImmersedN3D
remixed_from.title: Revised dual fan mount and shroud for Makerfarm i3 J-head

title: Adapter for jamesa's Makerfarm Fan mount

description.text: I wanted to use a 90 degree fan (because it was quieter) so I made this adapter so I could fit it on my currently printed mount and shroud by jamesa_Thingiverse. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:265388 I've included the Inventor Fusion file as well.

comments.text: How is this working out for you?  I ordered 2 blowers a few weeks ago.. still shipping.  I didn't realize I had cooling issues until i tried to print the small gear for the wades extruder!  I may have to give your adapter a try.
comments.author: ImmersedN3D

comments.text: Almost too well, the direction of the shroud makes it so that the near left corner gets more air than the other side, so I'm getting some curling on ABS parts. I've had to turn my fan down to about %60 for ABS parts.
comments.author: ImmersedN3D

author: bigluc

description.text: Skeg for a Kayak. This was was designed for the Intex K2 Inflatable Kayak, but I m sure it could be modified to fit others.

I m planning to CNC this out of .25" ABS.
you will need to Drill your own mounting holes.
For the Intex K2:
1- CNC part out of ABS (x2)
2- Drill two mounting holes in original skegs on bottom of Kayak.
3- Drill matching mounting holes in Skeg (toward front to allow the skeg to be placed farther back toward the rear of the kayak.)
4- Bolt CNCed Skegs to skegs on kayak.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274829 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=274829

indent_radius = 10
